crops.presented_by: Dr. Walter Koelz, through Prof. H. H. Bartlett
crops.institution_involved: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Mich.
crops.description: A low herbaceous perennial, not over 3 feet high, native to northern India. The compound leaves are made up of 5 to 9 deeply serrate, lanceolate leaflets 2 inches long, and the rose-colored, funnel-shaped flowers, 1 inch long, are borne in terminal racemes 6 to 8 inches long. Collected on sunny bare cliffs at Urni, Rampur, Bashahr.

crops.presented_by: Dr. Walter Koelz, through Prof. H. H. Bartlett
crops.institution_involved: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Mich.
crops.description: A low herbaceous perennial, not over 3 feet high, native to northern India. The compound leaves are made up of 5 to 9 deeply serrate, lanceolate leaflets 2 inches long, and the rose-colored, funnel-shaped flowers, 1 inch long, are borne in terminal racemes 6 to 8 inches long. Collected at Wangtu, Rampur, Bashahr.

crops.presented_by: Dr. Walter Koelz, through Prof. H. H. Bartlett
crops.institution_involved: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Mich.
crops.description: A wild white peach which becomes 30 feet high. The flowers are attractive, but the fruit is useless.

crops.presented_by: Dr. Walter Koelz, through Prof. H. H. Bartlett
crops.institution_involved: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Mich.
crops.description: A very attractive aster with purple flowers 6 inches in diameter.

crops.presented_by: Dr. Walter Koelz, through Prof. H. H. Bartlett
crops.institution_involved: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Mich.
crops.description: A thick-skinned, orange-colored lemon 6 inches long.

crops.presented_by: Dr. Walter Koelz, through Prof. H. H. Bartlett
crops.institution_involved: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Mich.
crops.description: An attractive vine with yellow flowers, found at 12,000 feet altitude in a cold dry situation.

crops.presented_by: Dr. Walter Koelz, through Prof. H. H. Bartlett
crops.institution_involved: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Mich.
crops.description: Found at 12,000 feet altitude in a dry cold situation.

crops.presented_by: Dr. Walter Koelz, through Prof. H. H. Bartlett
crops.institution_involved: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Mich.
crops.description: Found at 10,000 feet altitude.

crops.presented_by: Dr. Walter Koelz, through Prof. H. H. Bartlett
crops.institution_involved: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Mich.
crops.description: The coluteas are ornamental leguminous shrubs, useful as soil binders, found at 10,000 feet altitude.

crops.presented_by: Dr. Walter Koelz, through Prof. H. H. Bartlett
crops.institution_involved: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Mich.
crops.description: A very attractive shrub, 3 feet high, with dark-green leaves.

crops.presented_by: Dr. Walter Koelz, through Prof. H. H. Bartlett
crops.institution_involved: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Mich.
crops.description: A shrub 7 feet high, with very attractive carmine fruits, found in a dry cold region.

crops.presented_by: Dr. Walter Koelz, through Prof. H. H. Bartlett
crops.institution_involved: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Mich.
crops.description: A cultivated green pumpkin which grows chiefly in a hot climate.

crops.presented_by: Dr. Walter Koelz, through Prof. H. H. Bartlett
crops.institution_involved: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Mich.
crops.description: A tall herbaceous perennial, found growing in masses, with lanceolate leaves 1 to 2 feet long in a rosette at the base of the stem. This stem rises to 6 feet and bears a spike 2 to 3 feet long of white flowers. It is native to India, found at 13,000 feet altitude.

crops.presented_by: Dr. Walter Koelz, through Prof. H. H. Bartlett
crops.institution_involved: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Mich.
crops.description: A hardy spiny deciduous shrub with silvery foliage and orange-yellow fruits, found along watercourses, at 10,000 feet altitude.

crops.presented_by: Dr. Walter Koelz, through Prof. H. H. Bartlett
crops.institution_involved: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Mich.
crops.description: Found at 1,400 feet altitude.

crops.presented_by: Dr. Walter Koelz, through Prof. H. H. Bartlett
crops.institution_involved: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Mich.
crops.description: An attractive tree with a trunk 12 inches in diameter.

crops.presented_by: Dr. Walter Koelz, through Prof. H. H. Bartlett
crops.institution_involved: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Mich.
crops.description: Found in a field at 10,000 feet altitude.

crops.presented_by: Dr. Walter Koelz, through Prof. H. H. Bartlett
crops.institution_involved: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Mich.
crops.description: A vine which bears very fragrant white flowers throughout the summer.

crops.presented_by: Dr. Walter Koelz, through Prof. H. H. Bartlett
crops.institution_involved: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Mich.
crops.description: A prostrate annual mint with pale-lilac flowers; found in a dry cold atmosphere, at 10,000 feet altitude.

crops.presented_by: Dr. Walter Koelz, through Prof. H. H. Bartlett
crops.institution_involved: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Mich.
crops.description: A stout herb up to 3 feet high, white woolly throughout, with rounded cordate long-stemmed leaflets 1 to 3 inches across and dense whorls of rose-colored or purple flowers. Native to northwestern India at altitudes of 7,000 to 11,000 feet, found at 11,000 feet altitude.

crops.presented_by: Dr. Walter Koelz, through Prof. H. H. Bartlett
crops.institution_involved: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Mich.
crops.description: A lily, native to the Himalayas between 5,000 and 12,000 feet altitude, with bulbs that grow close to the surface. The hollow stems are 6 to 9 feet high, and the handsome cordate leaves are shining dark green above and paler beneath. The large fragrant white flowers, often 12 in a raceme, are slightly greenish without, and the inner surface of the segments is tinged with deep purple.

crops.presented_by: Dr. Walter Koelz, through Prof. H. H. Bartlett
crops.institution_involved: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Mich.
crops.description: A well-formed bush 7 feet high, with transparent white fruits that are eaten by birds, found on a cold semiarid slope at 10,000 feet altitude.

crops.presented_by: Dr. Walter Koelz, through Prof. H. H. Bartlett
crops.institution_involved: University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Mich.
crops.description: A small much-branched shrub with small, elliptic-orbicular, entire leaves, green and nearly glabrous above, more or less hairy beneath. The orange flowers are borne in pairs toward the ends of the branchlets. Native to the Himalayas, and closely allied to L. hypoleuca, found at 10,000 feet altitude.
